These verbs, consisting of a “verbalizer” and a noun, constitute the majority of verbs in Standard Spoken Tibetan. The noun may be replaced by an adjective, an adverb, or an onomatopoeia. Remember that the three main verbalizers are: བྱེད་ “to do” “to act,” རྒྱག་ “to make” “to do,” and བཏང་ “to send” “to do” (and their honorific equivalents).

The verbalizer may be preceded by a simple noun:

  • མོ་ཊ་བཏང་ “To drive a car”
  • གཞས་བཏང་ “To sing”
  • སྐད་བཏང་ “To call”
  • མེ་བཏང་ “To set fire”
  • སྐད་རྒྱག་ “To shout”

The verbalizer can also be preceded by an adjective:

  • སྐྱིད་པོ་བཏང་ “To have fun”
  • སྡུག་པོ་བཏང་ “To abuse”
  • དགའ་པོ་བྱེད་ “To like”
  • ཆུང་རུ་བཏང་ “To reduce”
  • ཆེ་རུ་བཏང་ “To enlarge”

The verbalizer can as well be preceded by a noun compound (see “Nominal Compounds,” above):

  • སློབ་སྦྱོང་བྱེད་ “To study”
  • སྒྱུར་བཅོས་བཏང་ “To reform”
  • ཡར་རྒྱས་བཏང་ “To improve”
  • སེམས་གསོ་བྱེད་ “To console”
  • གདན་འདྲེན་ཞུ་ “To invite”

Finally, the verbalizer can as well be preceded by a doubled form (with a verb, an adverb, an adjective or an onomatopoeia):

  • ཀྱོམ་ཀྱོམ་བྱེད་ To stir a liquid”
  • དཀྲུག་དཀྲུག་བཏང་ “To stir,” “to shake”
  • གཟབ་གཟབ་བྱེད་ “To be careful”
  • རུག་རུག་བྱེད་ “To gather”
  • ཕུར་ཕུར་བཏང་ “To massage,” “to stroke”
  • ལྷོད་ལྷོད་བྱེད་ “To relax”
